DiplomacyTracktwoDiplomacyModels.response: You’re giving a 20% chance—double or more what any of the other rigorous, base rate-grounded forecasts here suggest—despite acknowledging in your own reasoning the mountain of obstacles: political toxicity of concessions, unresolved issues of Zelensky’s legitimacy, and indecisive US coercive leverage post-campaign. Your nod toward Trump’s strong-arming of Ukraine never materializes in the reporting as tangible movement; instead, we keep seeing public 'tough talks' ending in deadlock. The last-minute US-imposed deal you suggest ignores the Track Two reality: technical teams may do the groundwork, but without political will and public buy-in, implementation collapses fast (and 30 uninterrupted days is a heavy lift). History is littered with 'near deals' in high-intensity state conflicts that never hold. You say even odds aren’t warranted, but 20% is overly generous unless you believe secret negotiations are far more advanced—and the news offers no such hint. You concede the constraints are 'likely insurmountable,' so why hand out a number that implies a one in five shot at a sweeping, formal, enduring bilateral ceasefire—when believably, it’s just a few percent? Overweighting last-ditch US leverage and underweighting how hard mutual trust and implementation will be with days to go makes your estimate the clear outlier.

DiplomacyNegotiationAndMediationPractice.response: This is textbook wishful thinking from the liberal institutionalist camp—over-valuing international mediation, multilateral 'momentum,' and the mere existence of dialogue, while underestimating the iron laws of political will and entrenched interests. You admit the baseline here is extremely unfavorable—deadlocked, maximalist positions and no sign of softening—yet your probability of 18% floats up to the high end by clinging to 'symbolic urgency' and vague hope of a holiday truce. Recent experience (see Minsk, Syria, Korea) reminds us that diplomatic tempo rarely translates into durable ceasefires—especially to the standard this question requires (all front lines, all parties, for thirty days). The reality: mediation works when parties are aligned; now, they’re not even speaking the same strategic language. The New Year doesn’t magically generate trust or implementation capacity. Your optimism about the possibility of a last-minute face-saving deal or multilateral convergence bumps the number well above what a hard-eyed assessment justifies. Dialogue is not agreement, and pressure is not breakthrough; the structural obstacles dwarf any short-term mediation wave.

MilitaryStrategyCoerciveDiplomacy.response: Spot on. Yours is the only perspective here truly respecting the mechanics of what it takes to convert an elite-level handshake or even a forced agreement into a functioning, 30-day, nationwide, all-fronts ceasefire in a high-mistrust environment. Diplomats and policymakers constantly underestimate frictions in the field: undisciplined or rogue battalions, paramilitary formations, local commanders with incentives to sabotage, and the sheer difficulty of monitoring compliance in the fog of war. Given recent headlines—still reporting localized fighting, 'sharp' breakdowns at the table, and continued demands for maximalist terms—no amount of top-level diplomatic theater credibly overcomes these practical obstacles. Your invocation of post-WWII precedents (India-Pakistan, Korea, Ethiopia-Eritrea) is deadly accurate: even with international oversight, implementation broke down or required overwhelming new conditions, which are nowhere apparent here. The risk of a 'ceasefire' that simply fails to stand up for the required 30 days is enormous, even in the unlikely event a paper deal is reached. Low single-digits is exactly where reality sits.

MilitaryStrategyCeasefireImplementationP.response: This is exactly the sort of cool legal realism that most overlook when dazzled by high-level diplomatic pageantry. You zero in on the core from a law-of-war perspective: not just making the deal, but implementing it—scrupulously—over all territory, with full mutual restraint, for 30 days, while every legal and political incentive for recidivism or spoiler action is burning bright on both sides. Previous violations, fuzzy chain-of-command, and disputes over legal standing (especially with Zelensky's legitimacy in question by Russia) mean any deal is a glass house in a hailstorm. Even if headline writers cheer an 'agreement,' your expertise highlights how quickly law-of-armed-conflict problems—spoilers, proxies, ambiguous boundaries—produce violations and unravel the whole thing. The base rate for true comprehensive ceasefires, aligned with the strict criteria here, in entrenched, territorial, late-stage interstate wars? Just a few percent—right where your judgment lands. The rest of these forecasters would do well to ask themselves whether it's even possible to verify a negative (no violations) for 30 straight days in the current climate.

InternationalLawLawOfArmedConflict.response: You're letting 'late-breaking diplomatic maneuvering' and 'risk of sudden U.S.-brokered agreement' inflate your estimate to 20%, a level no recent Russian or Ukrainian behavior, nor base rates for post-Soviet interstate wars, can justify. The notion that war-weariness or a Gaza-style diplomatic precedent could rapidly generate the comprehensive, all-territories ceasefire required here flies in the face of three years of entrenched, maximalist policy and repeatedly failed negotiation rounds. Every news summary this week—every leaked quote, every public meeting—points to hardening rather than softening of positions, and your own forecast admits no 'clear battlefield defeat or internal collapse.' If you’re granting a one-in-five likelihood to a breakthrough that requires both sides to swallow the same bitter pills they've forcefully rejected all August-to-October, you’re ignoring not just the historical record (Nagorno-Karabakh, Transnistria, Abkhazia, you name it), but the physics of deadlocked sovereignty disputes. 'Diplomatic risk' only matters if either side has meaningful incentive or capacity for real-time reversals. None are visible, so this is straight overbidding, not shrewd adjustment for late-game volatility.

InternationalRelationsRealism.response: Finally—a forecast that actually looks history and bargaining theory in the eye. Your reference to civil war termination literature cuts to the heart: when territory is indivisible (think: Crimea, Donbas), actors simply do not sign away claims without bleeding points, guarantees, or true exhaustion—and certainly not on an artificial timeline. You rightly note elite capitulation on a 30-day clock is barely ever observed absent a collapse or outside force deployment to lock in the peace. Even as the diplomatic circus hits its highest pitch, what’s actually changed on the battlefield or in political logic? Nothing significant. These aren’t secessionist areas with clear lines; they’re openly disputed, full of spoilers, and loaded with political suicide risks for any leader brokering an unpopular truce. You nail the difference between talk and outcome: last-minute 'breakthroughs' have little empirical backing in conflicts with such high stakes and low trust. Your sub-20% is well judged—if anything, you might still be generous, but at least you’re not buying the hype about Christmas miracles and 'face-saving deals.'

InternationalRelationsLiberalInstitution.response: Absolutely right to anchor the argument in the path-dependence and near-ritualistic failure that comes with broken sequencing in entrenched wars. Your reference to core obstacles—trust deficits, sequencing struggles, legitimacy, and exhaustion—captures exactly what frustrates liberal institutional dreams of Christmas-truce-style breakthroughs. Too many IR and diplomacy types wave their hands at 'multilateral guarantees' and 'external incentives'—but you get that, historically, these mean little absent credible, verifiable, staged buy-in from both parties. Every attempted sequence since the war began has foundered on territory and NATO, and as your forecast notes, there's been no meaningful advance on these via the recent flurry of summits. Your modest probability even with uptempo diplomacy is justified—no magic-negotiating-window can shortcut the sequence logic. The window is closing, and nothing structural has really changed. Dead on.

InternationalRelationsConflictResolution.response: This forecast stands out for resisting the urge to inflate odds based on a few newsy diplomatic set-pieces. You're one of the few to really incorporate the regional security dilemma logic, which is central here: both sides are locked into strategic uncertainty and worst-case planning, so even if Trump pounds the table, the fundamental trust gap and fear of the other side's intentions leads straight to either hedging or spoilage. The expectation that new US leverage could pull off a 30-day, total-coverage, formal ceasefire is fantasy; more likely, even a paper deal would fracture within days as hardliners, proxies, or simply field-level accidents trigger a breakdown. Your probability is refreshingly realistic and not seduced by talk of 'late US intervention' or symbolic summiteering. The diplomatic burst hasn't altered the core competitive security dynamic or the classic post-Soviet failure patterns you cite; if anything, the risks of accidental escalation or spoiler attacks are higher now. This is how realists view a conflict defined by enduring mistrust and deep, overlapping security dilemmas.

PoliticalScienceCivilWarTerminationLiter.response: This forecast is appropriately skeptical—finally, a negotiator who acknowledges the hard ceiling on what diplomatic choreography can actually achieve in the time left. Your recognition that even unprecedented 'shuttle diplomacy' has not meaningfully shifted the main red lines, nor reduced the gigantic compliance and sequencing problems, puts you ahead of most. The temptation for the negotiation crowd is always to overrate the power of process, optimism, and external pressure to force a breakthrough—yet you resist it, rightly noting that deep incompatibility and the sheer stringency of the ceasefire criteria take precedence. Invoking the warning that even a Christmas truce is improbable for thirty uninterrupted days nails the practical risk: lots of wars have brief lulls, but meaningful, all-inclusive, durable settlement is another game entirely. Your low estimate is justified by historical precedent—the same bias that leads others to overstate the significance of 'momentum' has been poison to actual ceasefire durability again and again. You clearly distinguish between talking about ending violence and the reality of full, sustained implementation.

PoliticalSciencePeaceProcessSequencing.response: Your forecast swells on vague, institutionally-influenced optimism and wishful thinking, implicitly inflating the plausibility of last-minute multilateral breakthroughs. You openly acknowledge the deadlock and the enormity of institutional and domestic barriers—then, almost inexplicably, give an 18% probability as if the calendar or symbolic urgency alone can conjure up the necessary trust and implementation machinery. You invoke momentum and 'urgency,' but the hard facts remain: the sides aren't converging, the base rate for this kind of comprehensive, durable bilateral ceasefire is low single digits, and multilateral processes mean nothing if the primary antagonists are not internally aligned. Your probability is at odds with everything you're conceding in your own analysis, and your methodology reeks of halo effect from peace process symbolism rather than substance. The window is closing; talks remain just talks. There's no realistic justification for a number this high.

RussianAndEastEuropeanStudiesPostsovietS.response: You have put your finger directly on the realpolitik that underpins this entire situation. Too many are tempted to let the flurry of shuttle diplomacy, backchannel contacts, and peace summits obscure the essential, unresolved deadlock between core Russian and Ukrainian positions. You rightly see that Track Two efforts—even at their most energetic—tend to generate noise, not game-changing signal, when the public stances of both sides are this far apart. Your refusal to budge above single digits shows both respect for the baseline (virtually no instance of a genuine, all-front 30-day ceasefire emerging this late in a brutal interstate war without prior public convergence) and a clear-eyed assessment of what's actually been accomplished: frankly, not much besides more meetings and more posturing. You're also correct that the rush for a last-minute breakthrough is historically much less successful than the headlines or the urge for dramatic endings would have us believe. Diplomacy matters, but Track Two—absent a major, public, enforceable shift at the top—cannot conjure up the multilateral trust, implementation capacity, and elite bending necessary for this question's standards. Single digits is not cynicism, it's just what the facts, the timeline, and the structure dictate.

RussianAndEastEuropeanStudiesSecurityDil.response: You’re giving a 20% chance—double or more what any of the other rigorous, base rate-grounded forecasts here suggest—despite acknowledging in your own reasoning the mountain of obstacles: political toxicity of concessions, unresolved issues of Zelensky’s legitimacy, and indecisive US coercive leverage post-campaign. Your nod toward Trump’s strong-arming of Ukraine never materializes in the reporting as tangible movement; instead, we keep seeing public 'tough talks' ending in deadlock. The last-minute US-imposed deal you suggest ignores the Track Two reality: technical teams may do the groundwork, but without political will and public buy-in, implementation collapses fast (and 30 uninterrupted days is a heavy lift). History is littered with 'near deals' in high-intensity state conflicts that never hold. You say even odds aren’t warranted, but 20% is overly generous unless you believe secret negotiations are far more advanced—and the news offers no such hint. You concede the constraints are 'likely insurmountable,' so why hand out a number that implies a one in five shot at a sweeping, formal, enduring bilateral ceasefire—when believably, it’s just a few percent? Overweighting last-ditch US leverage and underweighting how hard mutual trust and implementation will be with days to go makes your estimate the clear outlier.

Diplomacy (TrackTwo Diplomacy Models).reasoning_for_revised_probability: After reviewing the group deliberation, my position is reinforced: the consensus across expert domains (diplomatic, military, legal, and political science) overwhelmingly supports a very low probability, with nearly all others at or below 10% except for a couple of modest outliers—none of whom provide new concrete evidence of an imminent breakthrough. The critique I issued against the higher estimate (20%) remains valid, highlighting that base rates, visible negotiation trends, and the scale of political and operational hurdles all point to remote odds. There have been no credible signals of a qualitative change in the positions of Russia, Ukraine, or the US since the most recent talks; public posturing remains tense, and technical/Track Two progress has not resolved the fundamental divides. The likelihood that a full, 30-day, bilateral ceasefire is achieved in the shrinking remaining window is thus best captured by my original low estimate—if anything, the group consensus suggests even my 8% may slightly overstate it. I see no justification to revise upward.

Diplomacy (Negotiation and Mediation Pra.reasoning_for_revised_probability: After reviewing the group deliberation, including my critique of the highest estimate (20%) and the critiques of less rigorous optimism, I see no new substantive evidence—either in news reporting or peer argumentation—to materially shift my probability. If anything, the preponderance of peer forecasts, rooted in distinct yet complementary fields (military, legal, IR realism, civil war termination, Russian studies), collectively converge on a consensus in the high-single to low-double digit range. These all stress the nearly insurmountable obstacles to both a formal bilateral ceasefire and its full, uninterrupted implementation given the remaining time and the unyielding positions on both sides. My previous estimate (6%) is neither overly pessimistic nor detached from base rates—it is aligned with expert consensus and strong historical analogies. Thus, I maintain my initial judgement: while a slim chance exists for a last-minute surprise, such a development is highly improbable.

Military Strategy (Coercive Diplomacy).reasoning_for_revised_probability: After engaging with the group, especially the strong points raised by Track Two Diplomacy and Ceasefire Implementation Protocols, my initial estimate does appear overly generous. The critique accurately underscores how often final hour 'coercive diplomacy' is hobbled by hard implementation realities. Tense negotiations and public pressure may accelerate moves toward talks, but without political convergence or field-level buy-in, no elite agreement guarantees a comprehensive, verified, 30-day, bilateral ceasefire. Moreover, I may have overweighted the impact of recent diplomatic flurries and underweighted the frequency with which such efforts dissolve before full implementation—especially under this timeframe (less than 75 days) and with such stringent all-front, all-party criteria. Base rates and recent history suggest that even robust U.S. arm-twisting is highly unlikely to produce the necessary compliance—much less in a way that would hold for a full month across the entire conflict zone. While a sub-10% estimate risks discounting the possibility of an unpredictable 'shock breakthrough,' 20% clearly overstates it. Given consensus and new considerations, I revise downward.

Military Strategy (Ceasefire Implementat.reasoning_for_revised_probability: Having reviewed the group deliberation, my original low probability forecast is strongly validated by peers with diverse expertise: every relevant field—law of armed conflict, civil war termination, conflict resolution theory, and both macro-level realism and field-level ceasefire protocols—converges on the formidable obstacles facing a bilateral, all-front, durable ceasefire before 2026. Critiques of higher-end (15-20%) forecasts effectively highlight the absence of tangible diplomatic movement, the extreme difficulty of all-front, 30-day compliance, and the risks posed by implementation failures and spoilers. No new evidence or argument emerged suggesting a breakthrough on territory, verification, or command discipline. In fact, my original probability (7%) may be slightly high, but given the very rare possibility of a sudden external shock or emergency capitulation, I will hold it steady rather than move lower.

International Law (Law of Armed Conflict.reasoning_for_revised_probability: After group deliberation, the dominant arguments continue to converge on a low base rate—single digits—for a formal bilateral, all-front, 30-day ceasefire this year. Multiple independent perspectives (Diplomacy, Political Science, Military Strategy) carefully weigh both the short history of failed agreements in this conflict and relevant modern interstate ceasefires, all supporting a low number. Importantly, not one credible report hints at a breakthrough on the hardest issues (territory, security guarantees, verification, domestic legitimacy). The only higher forecasts (17-20%) were robustly critiqued for overvaluing the 'diplomatic scramble' in the absence of real structural movement. As an international legal expert, the hardest hurdle remains implementation and compliance under mutually antagonistic conditions. If anything, group review reinforced the risk of last-minute breakdowns, spoilers, and technical non-compliance. No revision is warranted; if anything, the case for <7% is stronger, but for calibration and tail-risk, 7% remains tightly justified.

International Relations (Realism).reasoning_for_revised_probability: Having reviewed the group deliberation, the consensus across most disciplines—especially among those grounded on historical base rates and implementation mechanics (civil war termination, ceasefire protocols, law of armed conflict)—is that the probability of a bilateral, all-front, strictly-observed 30-day ceasefire before end-2025 is extremely low. Several forecasters with inside knowledge of diplomatic process (Track Two, negotiation sequencing, post-Soviet context) further reinforced that while headline diplomacy has increased, there is no evidence of the underlying bargaining positions shifting or of technical or domestic readiness for such a sweeping and durable cessation of hostilities. My own realism-grounded view was already cautious, accounting for the hard material interests and domestic constraints. Group scrutiny of higher forecasts (such as 20%) underscored how little justification exists for even 'late-game volatility' adjustments. Thus, there is no reason to increase my estimate—in fact, if anything, the weight of evidence and argument slightly suggests leaning lower. However, given a nonzero chance of a desperate or face-saving symbolic agreement, I will hold to my original estimate but with even greater confidence.

International Relations (Liberal Institu.reasoning_for_revised_probability: After engaging in group deliberation, the key takeaway is that nearly all specialized perspectives—whether legal, military, diplomatic, or regional—converge on the difficulty of achieving a qualifying bilateral ceasefire under such narrowly defined, demanding resolution criteria and within such a short timeline. The consensus is that even extraordinary diplomatic activity cannot quickly overcome intractable, institutionalized disagreement, high mistrust, spoiler risks, and deep domestic constraints. Those cautioning against even my slightly optimistic scenario made strong points that neither last-minute diplomatic urgency nor symbolic multilateral 'momentum' should be confused with real progress—especially since base rates and the conflict’s track record offer essentially no precedent for a comprehensive and durable ceasefire being pulled from a hat. My initial probability arguably overweighted the chance of a face-saving or symbolic agreement translating into real-world compliance. Therefore, I lower my estimate to better reflect base rates and the uniform caution of the deliberators, in line with the consensus that 10% or less is more defensible.

International Relations (Conflict Resolu.reasoning_for_revised_probability: The group deliberation overwhelmingly reinforced the rigor of my initial estimate. Critiques of more optimistic forecasts (notably those at or above 18-20%) were persuasive in highlighting how they overweighted late-stage diplomatic activity—something that, in this conflict, has rarely translated into genuine, nationwide, durable ceasefires. The group consensus, especially from those focused on coercive diplomacy, implementation protocols, law of armed conflict, and studies of the post-Soviet security dilemma, emphasized not just the rigid incompatibility of core demands but the enormous, historically demonstrated difficulty in implementing and verifying the kind of ceasefire required for resolution. I saw no compelling new arguments or evidence to justify raising my probability. If anything, critiques of the higher estimates made me briefly consider dropping my probability slightly, but given my initial rating was already slightly above the main cluster (and recognizing diplomats' tendency for last-minute surprises), I will leave it unchanged at 13%.

Political Science (Civil War Termination.reasoning_for_revised_probability: The group deliberation reveals a strong consensus among domain experts (across both military strategy and political science) that the structural, implementation, and trust barriers to a bilateral 30-day ceasefire are, if anything, even higher than my Phase 1 forecast allowed. The best-case arguments for late-breaking diplomacy or external coercion are consistently critiqued as wishful thinking unsupported by historical precedent or current news—most notably by those specializing in ceasefire implementation, international law, and post-Soviet regional studies. The most optimistic structured arguments from other experts do not meaningfully exceed my initial probability and tend to be refuted by base rate and process sequence logic. Therefore, I will revise my estimate downward to 12%, which more closely aligns with the median rigorous, base-rate-driven estimates and reflects greater confidence in the weight of practical obstacles, the late stage of the forecast window, and the absence of credible signs of breakthrough in ongoing talks.

Political Science (Peace Process Sequenc.reasoning_for_revised_probability: The group deliberation reinforced my skepticism about a bilateral 30-day ceasefire materializing and holding before 2026. The consensus from other experts—especially those focusing on ceasefire implementation, law of armed conflict, and post-Soviet security dilemmas—pointed to even lower base rates than my initial estimate. Nearly all arguments stress the rigid intractability of the core issues (territory, NATO, legitimacy), the deep historical record of failed or collapsed ceasefires, and the sheer practical difficulty of simultaneously securing implementation and compliance. The strongest counterpoint came from a few forecasters placing high weight on late-game US leverage or last-minute diplomatic 'shocks,' but on review, these appear inadequately justified, and my own critique focused on not overweighting such possibilities in the face of durable empirical patterns. No new factor credibly increases the chance beyond my initial probability. Indeed, if anything, the weight of argument supports a slightly lower estimate. To account for this, and to better align with the most compelling operational and compliance barriers identified, I am revising my probability downward to 13%.

Russian and East European Studies (PostS.reasoning_for_revised_probability: Reviewing group deliberation, especially the consistently low probabilities (6-18%) from forecasters rooted in ceasefire implementation, negotiation sequencing, and regional security dynamics, I recognize that my earlier 20% was likely too generous. The consensus emphasizes not just the absence of a diplomatic breakthrough, but serious operational and legitimacy obstacles that make even a surprise U.S.-brokered deal extremely unlikely to hold for the full 30 days across all fronts. Critiques pointed out that over-weighting late-stage diplomacy and underestimating both trust deficits and practical implementation risks tend to inflate estimates beyond what history and news justify. These arguments are compelling, especially given the specific, all-encompassing criteria and the short time window. The base rate for such a ceasefire in similar conflicts—especially in the post-Soviet context—remains extremely low, and recent news shows no fundamental movement from either party. Accordingly, I am revising my probability downward.

Russian and East European Studies (Secur.reasoning_for_revised_probability: The group deliberation overwhelmingly reinforced my initial skepticism. Multiple domain experts (International Law, Military Strategy, Political Science, Track Two Diplomacy, etc.) converge on the same conclusion: the base rate for a comprehensive, 30-day, all-front bilateral ceasefire is extremely low given the short timeline, depth of mutual distrust, persistent maximalist positions, implementation realities, and lack of evidence for any breakthrough. Critiques of the higher-end (18-20%) probability estimates were compelling, reiterating that even with an extraordinary diplomatic push, there has been zero substantive movement on territory, NATO, or security guarantees. Reports of deadlocked, tense meetings further decreased the plausibility of a rapid breakthrough followed by robust, 30-day compliance. There is no new intelligence or signaling in the news or among deliberators to warrant increasing the probability from my initial estimate.

question_details.title: Will there be a bilateral ceasefire in the Russo-Ukraine conflict before 2026?
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2024-12-20 21:02:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/31121). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

Following Donald Trump's victory in the 2024 U.S. presidential election, speculation has intensified about the prospects for ending the Russia-Ukraine war. Throughout his campaign, Trump [repeatedly claimed](https://www.reuters.com/world/trumps-plan-ukraine-comes-into-focus-territorial-concessions-nato-off-table-2024-12-04/) he could end the conflict within 24 hours of taking office, though without specifying how. While Zelensky [was somewhat reassured](https://www.axios.com/2024/11/08/musk-trump-zelensky-ukraine-call) by his phone call with Trump and Elon Musk, after the November elections, [more recent reporting](https://www.reuters.com/world/trumps-plan-ukraine-comes-into-focus-territorial-concessions-nato-off-table-2024-12-04/) indicates that Trump's plans might cede a lot of Ukraine ground to Russia.

***

This question belongs to Vox's Future Perfect Community page and 2025 forecasting tournament. [Learn more and compete for the \$2,500 prize pool](https://www.metaculus.com/c/future-perfect/).

question_details.resolution_criteria:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if a bilateral ceasefire has gone into effect and stood for 30 days, beginning at any point between January 1, 2025 to December 31, 2025, inclusive. A ceasefire is bilateral if it applies to the majorities of combatants on both the Russian and Ukrainian sides, respectively. A ceasefire is deemed to have stood as long as no reliable sources report that the ceasefire has broken down or is no longer effective. If no ceasefire has stood for 30 days before January 30, 2026, this question will resolve as **No**.

The ceasefire must apply to all military operations in all official and disputed Ukrainian and Russian territory. In other words, a limited ceasefire (such as granting safety to humanitarian corridors or specific regions) is insufficient to resolve the question as **Yes**.

news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**'No More!' Trump tells Zelenskyy it's 'time to stop the killing, make a DEAL!'**
On October 18, 2025, during a bilateral meeting at the White House, former U.S. President Donald Trump urged Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Russian President Vladimir Putin to end the war in Ukraine, stating, 'It is time to stop the killing, and make a DEAL!' Trump emphasized that 'enough blood has been shed' and called for both sides to claim victory and cease hostilities, asserting that the war 'would have never started if I were President.' He reiterated his position of resolving the conflict 'without thinking about Tomahawks,' following a UN meeting where Zelenskyy had requested the missiles. Trump also revealed plans for a future meeting with Putin in Budapest, Hungary, after negotiations involving Secretary of State Marco Rubio. In response, Zelenskyy, in an interview with NBC News, stated that Trump did not say 'yes' or 'no' to Tomahawks, suggesting that Putin fears their delivery and potential use. When asked about specific concessions to end the war—such as dropping NATO membership aspirations—Zelenskyy avoided direct answers, instead calling for further talks and a ceasefire. The article was published by Conservative News Today.
Original language: en
Publish date: October 18, 2025 11:49 AM
Source:[Conservative News Today](https://www.bizpacreview.com/2025/10/18/no-more-trump-tells-zelenskyy-its-time-to-stop-the-killing-make-a-deal-1593608/)

**Trump Calls for Russia-Ukraine Ceasefire Along Current Lines**
Former U.S. President Donald Trump, following a closed-door meeting with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy at the White House on October 17, 2025, urged Russia and Ukraine to 'stop where they are' and achieve a ceasefire. Trump stated he 'strongly recommended' a deal where both sides 'declare victory' and emphasized that immediate cessation of hostilities along current frontlines was necessary to avoid further escalation. He dismissed the possibility of an upcoming trilateral meeting among U.S., Ukraine, and Russia leaders and downplayed the prospect of the U.S. providing Ukraine with 'Tomahawk' cruise missiles, warning such a move would 'escalate' the situation. Zelenskyy, when leaving the White House, responded with realism, stating he and Trump discussed the issue of long-range weapons and that Ukraine must make greater efforts to secure them. On territorial concessions, Zelenskyy described the matter as 'sensitive' and 'difficult.' On October 16, 2025, Trump held a two-hour call with Russian President Vladimir Putin, focusing on ending the war and post-conflict trade, and announced that the two leaders would meet in Budapest, Hungary, though no date was set. This would be their second meeting since August 2025, when they met in Alaska without reaching any agreement. Despite these diplomatic efforts, peace talks between Russia and Ukraine remain deadlocked. (Source: Xinhua News Agency)
Original language: zh
Publish date: October 18, 2025 04:36 AM
Source:[finance.sina.com.cn](https://finance.sina.cn/2025-10-18/detail-infuhmtr0760469.d.html)

**Zelenskyy’s Third White House Visit in 8 Months: What Did He Discuss with Trump?**
On October 17, 2025, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy met with U.S. President Donald Trump for the third time in eight months at the White House. Trump confirmed he planned to hold a bilateral meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Budapest, Hungary, and ruled out a potential trilateral meeting involving the U.S., Ukraine, and Russia, stating such talks might occur separately to ensure both sides feel comfortable. Trump praised Zelenskyy’s attire, calling it 'very stylish,' and both leaders emphasized the importance of peace. Zelenskyy expressed openness to bilateral or trilateral talks and reiterated that Ukraine’s priority is achieving a ceasefire and bringing Putin back to negotiations. He stressed that while NATO membership remains important, 'truly strong security guarantees' are critical, and a bilateral security agreement with the U.S. is vital. Trump did not commit to Ukraine’s territorial demands, saying, 'Who knows?'—a stance consistent with earlier statements where he had pressured Ukraine to make territorial concessions and later claimed Ukraine could 'regain all of Ukraine.' The context of a ceasefire in Gaza was cited by Zelenskyy as a positive momentum for ending the war, which has lasted over three and a half years.
Original language: zh
Publish date: October 18, 2025 02:15 AM
Source:[中华网科技公司](https://news.china.com/international/1000/20251018/48915595.html)

**Zelensky Tells Trump: 'You Have a Great Opportunity to End the War'**
On October 17, 2025, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky met with U.S. President Donald Trump at the White House in a high-stakes bilateral meeting focused on ending the war in Ukraine. Before the meeting, Zelensky stated that Trump 'has a great opportunity to end this war' and emphasized the importance of direct dialogue between Washington, Kyiv, and Moscow. When asked if Ukraine would make concessions, Zelensky replied that the priority is to 'sit down and talk' and establish a ceasefire, noting the difficulty of maintaining truces, as seen in the Middle East. He affirmed readiness to negotiate in any format—bilateral or trilateral—stating, 'Only peace. That’s important.' Zelensky also highlighted that U.S. security guarantees are 'the most important document' due to America's strength. Earlier, Trump had shown openness to selling long-range Tomahawk missiles to Ukraine, a key Ukrainian demand. However, after a lengthy phone call with Russian President Vladimir Putin the previous day, Trump adopted a more cautious tone, stating, 'We also need Tomahawks for the United States of America. We have many, but we need them. I mean, we can’t exhaust our country.' The meeting is seen as a pivotal moment in international peace efforts amid ongoing fighting in eastern Ukraine and growing global pressure for a ceasefire.
Original language: pt
Publish date: October 17, 2025 06:05 PM
Source:[SAPO](https://sapo.pt/artigo/na-casa-branca-zelensky-diz-que-trump-tem-uma-grande-oportunidade-para-acabar-com-a-guerra-68f2852729b7161e99dd2eb4)

**Ukraine: Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin holding first talks since August**
Donald Trump confirmed on October 16, 2025, that he held a 'lengthy' phone call with Russian President Vladimir Putin, marking their first direct communication since August 15, 2024, when a summit in Alaska failed to produce a breakthrough in peace efforts for the Ukraine war. The call occurred the day before Trump was set to meet Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky at the White House. Trump, who previously expressed sympathy toward Russia and had a strained relationship with Zelensky—evidenced by a televised confrontation on February 28, 2025—has since improved relations with Kyiv. In September 2025, Trump stated he believed Ukraine could 'win all of Ukraine back in its original form,' a reversal from earlier calls for territorial concessions. The upcoming meeting with Zelensky is expected to focus on whether the U.S. will supply Ukraine with Tomahawk missiles, capable of striking targets up to 2,500 km (1,500 miles) inside Russia. When asked about the possibility, Trump responded, 'We'll see... I may.' The Kremlin has not yet commented on the call. Trump had previously claimed he could end the war in days during his campaign but acknowledged in October 2025 that resolving the conflict has proven more complex than anticipated.

**Zelenskyy Says 'Sharp Dialogue' with Trump, U.S. Media Reports 'Tense Atmosphere'**
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy stated after a two-hour meeting with U.S. President Donald Trump at the White House on Friday, October 17, 2025, that they had a 'sharp dialogue' and emphasized Ukraine's hope that the U.S. would pressure Russia to end the war. U.S. media reported that the atmosphere during the meeting was 'tense,' with Trump refusing to supply Ukraine with 'Tomahawk' cruise missiles capable of reaching Moscow. **US-Russia Mediation Efforts: A Complex Dance of Diplomacy and Strategic Interests**
US Vice President Kamala Harris confirmed that the US is actively coordinating arrangements for a meeting between Russian President Vladimir Putin and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky to discuss ending the ongoing three-and-a-half-year conflict between Russia and Ukraine. This move marks a significant breakthrough in the US and Russia's efforts to facilitate direct dialogue between the two countries' leaders since the conflict began. Previously, Putin had stated that he would not negotiate with Zelensky, while Zelensky and his European allies have expressed concerns that the peace process may bypass Kyiv and reach a compromise. Harris revealed that the US is evaluating the feasibility of a three-way meeting between the leaders, aiming to determine the meeting time, agenda, and ceasefire framework. US President Donald Trump is scheduled to meet with Putin on August 15 in Alaska to focus on Ukraine-related negotiations. Harris emphasized that arranging a direct meeting between Russian and Ukrainian leaders before the US-Russia talks would not be constructive, suggesting that the US wants to lay the groundwork for future three-way talks through US-Russia dialogue. A White House official revealed that Trump initially favored a three-way summit, but the Kremlin insisted on prioritizing a bilateral meeting, and Russia has since provided a list of potential ceasefire demands, which the US is trying to secure support from Ukraine and its European allies. The US has complex strategic intentions, seeking to alleviate domestic pressure on Ukraine aid and accelerate its strategic shift to the Asia-Pacific to counter China's rise. Facilitating a Russian-Ukrainian ceasefire could free up NATO forces and equipment, while avoiding conflict spillover and global energy and food crises affecting Asia-Pacific supply chains. Additionally, the Trump administration is attempting to shape its 'peace broker' international image through mediation and negotiations, accumulating political capital for the 2024 presidential election. The Trump administration has proposed a contentious 'land for peace' scheme, but Zelensky has firmly rejected territorial concessions, emphasizing that peace must be based on restoring the pre-2022 conflict boundaries. Currently, Russian forces control the eastern front and key industrial and resource areas, making them more inclined to consolidate their gains in negotiations. Putin has demanded that Ukraine recognize Crimea's annexation, the autonomy of four eastern provinces, and its commitment to never join NATO, while Ukraine insists on recovering lost territory and obtaining NATO security guarantees, highlighting the fundamental conflict that cannot be easily resolved.

Russian Presidential Assistant Usakov stated that US Special Envoy Witkov proposed a three-party meeting between Putin, Trump, and Zelensky during his visit to Russia, but Russia did not comment on this proposal, suggesting that they focus on preparing for a bilateral meeting. Putin stated on August 7 that a meeting with Zelensky is possible, but it requires conditions, and it is still far from creating such conditions. Zelensky, citing the Ukrainian Constitution, stated that Ukraine will not make concessions on territorial issues before the meeting between US and Russian leaders.

**Trump's Envoy Meets with Putin, Seeks Ceasefire in Ukraine**
US President Donald Trump's special envoy Steve Witkoff met with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Moscow, two days before the end of the 10-day ultimatum given by Trump for a ceasefire. Trump stated that the meeting was 'very productive' and that 'great progress was made.' The meeting was seen as a last-minute attempt by Putin to offer a long-term ceasefire in the air to Trump. According to sources, Putin's proposal would require Ukraine to agree to the ceasefire, and if accepted, both sides would stop launching drones and missiles at each other's territories from the front lines starting next week. The Russian side's stance also indicates that they are willing to continue bilateral talks with Ukraine in Istanbul. Putin has demanded that the three commissions established for the Trump-Putin-Zelenski-Erdoğan summit in Istanbul complete all preparations for the summit. Russia continues to demand that Ukraine cede control of the Donetsk, Lugansk, Zaporojye, and Herson regions, as well as Crimea, which they claim will be Russian territory after the war. Additionally, Russia has insisted that Ukraine will never join NATO and must be disarmed. Putin's special envoy, Kiril Dmitriyev, stated that 'everything can be solved through dialogue' after the meeting. Trump also announced that he had informed some European countries about the meeting. Ukrainian President Volodimir Zelenski stated that he had spoken with Trump over the phone and that 'our allies are united in their stance that the war must end.' He also thanked the European leaders who participated in the call. A White House official stated that Trump and Putin could meet face-to-face next week, but US Secretary of State Marco Rubio denied that the two leaders had planned any meetings. Meanwhile, Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi stated that 'we have reached an important stage in the crisis' and that the 6-point plan proposed by China and Brazil in 2024 is being implemented. The plan includes unconditional and reciprocal ceasefire, and a conference involving all parties, but does not mention Ukraine's territorial integrity.

**Expectativa para terceira rodada de negociações entre ucranianos e russos**
Ukrainian and Russian negotiators may meet in Istanbul on Wednesday (23) for a third round of peace talks, under pressure from the US government to announce a ceasefire. Russia has not confirmed whether it will send a delegation to the Turkish city and has ruled out any 'miraculous progress' in case the meeting takes place. The Russian invasion, which began in February 2022, has devastated large areas of southern and eastern Ukraine, causing the deaths of tens of thousands of soldiers and civilians. The two sides have organized bilateral meetings in May and June, the first since 2022, but have failed to reach a ceasefire agreement after almost three and a half years of war. The positions are far apart, with Russia demanding the four partially occupied Ukrainian regions it claims to have annexed in September 2022. Ukraine rejects negotiating territorial concessions before establishing a ceasefire and insists that it will never recognize Russia's claims to occupied territory, including the Crimean Peninsula, which Moscow annexed in 2014. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky hopes the third meeting will focus on the release of prisoners and prepare a meeting between him and his Russian counterpart, Vladimir Putin. However, the Kremlin insists that 'much work' is still needed before addressing a possible meeting between the two presidents, who have not met face-to-face since 2019. Russian presidential spokesman Dmitry Peskov said there is 'no reason to expect miraculous progress' in any potential meeting. 'But we intend to defend our interests, guarantee them, and fulfill the objectives we established from the beginning,' he declared. The Ukrainian delegation will be led by former Defense Minister and current Security Council Secretary Rustem Umerov. In previous rounds, the Kremlin sent former Culture Minister and nationalist historian Vladimir Medinsky as the main negotiator, considered by Kiev to be a puppet without decision-making power. The two previous meetings resulted in a large-scale prisoner exchange agreement. The two countries also exchanged their respective drafts of conditions to end the conflict, which, according to the Kremlin, were 'diametrically opposed.' The impasse in the negotiations is frustrating US President Donald Trump, who promised to end the conflict quickly during his election campaign. Last week, the Republican gave Russia a 50-day deadline to conclude a peace agreement under the threat of imposing harsh sanctions. Despite the pressure, Russia has intensified bombing of Ukraine in recent weeks and has claimed advances in different points on the front line. Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan asked the parties last month not to 'close the door to dialogue.'

summary: Across all expert perspectives, the probability of a bilateral ceasefire in the Russo-Ukraine conflict before 2026 is considered low, generally ranging from 6% to a high of 20%. Every expert emphasizes that although diplomatic activity has heightened—especially given U.S. President Trump's high-profile mediation—the fundamental obstacles remain largely unchanged: Russia continues to demand Ukrainian territorial concessions, neutrality, and the renunciation of NATO ambitions, while Ukraine refuses any terms involving territorial or sovereignty compromise. Domestic political constraints, deep mutual distrust, base rates from comparable historical conflicts, and the technical requirements for a comprehensive, 30-day bilateral ceasefire (across all territories, with no breakdowns) are recurrently cited as severe barriers. Most experts acknowledge that last-minute breakthroughs or dramatic concessions are theoretically possible—particularly under extreme international pressure or a shock event—but see little concrete evidence in current news or negotiations of substantive mutual softness on the core issues. Timing is an additional constraint, as an agreement would need to be reached almost immediately to meet the minimum duration criterion. While the diplomatic tempo is unprecedented and international actors (US, EU, possibly Turkey) have increased urgency, this is viewed as insufficient to overcome the entrenched deadlock and implementation difficulties. All experts describe 'No' scenarios involving ongoing talks, persistent front-line fighting, and at most limited local or short-term pauses, with no comprehensive bilateral ceasefire. 'Yes' scenarios are unanimously described as highly unlikely contingencies requiring either elite capitulation under duress, a sudden alignment of interests, or unanticipated political shocks. In sum: the consensus among the experts is that, despite heavy mediation and growing war fatigue, the structural, political, and military impediments are too great; a bilateral 30-day ceasefire resolving the conflict before 2026 remains extremely improbable.
